properties.name: City Hotel
properties.description: Posted by Thegnu The City Hotel was probably the first hotel in Elgin. In March 1880 it was operated by Mrs M E Reed and later known as Meeks Hotel, owned by Frank and Lucretia Arbuckle Meeks. It burned in October 1898.

properties.name: Courier Building
properties.description: Posted by Thegnu  This building, which now houses Advocacy Outreach, was built in 1910 for the Elgin weekly newspaper. The Elgin Courier has been in continuous operation since 1890, although they have long moved out of this elderly printing facility.

properties.name: Elgin Depot Museum
properties.description: Posted by Thegnu Elgin Depot museum is open Tues-Sun 2-5 pm. There is a permanent exhibit of Elgin history, which is rich with information on the transportation history of the area. There are temporary exhibits also. The former baggage room contains the extensive archive of the Elgin Historical Association.

properties.name: First Light Plant in Elgin
properties.description: Posted by Thegnu Elgin Light & Power Co. was established in 1910 by Thomas Deisch (left. Reggie Gober, center. Aubrey Jefferson right.)

properties.name: Foehner's Grocery
properties.description: Posted by Thegnu 1953 Margarete Bartosh at Foehner Grocery.

properties.name: H&TC Cotton train
properties.description: Posted by Thegnu Eastbound Houston & Texas Central cotton train in 1908. Cotton loading dock is behind at the old H&TC depot (now the Elgin Chamber of Commerce). Joe King and Max Hirsch stand by the train.

properties.name: Hanke Gin
properties.description: Posted by Thegnu There has been a gin on this site since 1878 when Silas Chatfield built a gin and grist mill. Henry Hanke bought the steam gin from John S Smith in 1883 and the Hanke gin (rebuilt in 1917) operated continuously until 1969. The photo from 1909 shows the gin buildings as well as the old (right center) and new (right) Hanke houses. Mike Hanke still lives on the property.

properties.name: Johnson's Nursing Home
properties.description: Posted by Thegnu This building started out life as a red brick hotel. It went through several owners and in its last years served as a nursing home, the bricks having been painted white. In 1959 new state regulations for homes with more than 3 residents (Mrs Balch, the long time manager had up to 34) meant that the home had to close. Matt Burleson, Justice of the Peace in Elgin for years, was the last resident.

properties.name: Magnolia Service Station
properties.description: Posted by Thegnu Magnolia Service Station. Early 1930s. Jim Harris was owner/operator. He also sold wholesale for Magnolia products. On the right is probably Jim Harris and J O Smith with daughter Amy.

properties.name: Main Street 1916
properties.description: Posted by Thegnu

properties.name: McClellan Inn
properties.description: Posted by Thegnu The McClellan Inn was built in 1908 of timbers from the Ben Hur, a huge pleasure craft which plied the waters of the Colorado River in the 1890s, affording the elite of Austin and Central Texas the tops in entertainment. Tom Pfeiffer of Elgin purchased and dismantled the vessel, using the lumber for building the Inn. The McClellan had 22 bedrooms and was lighted throughout with acetylene. The hotel was leased to Miss Ethel McClellan (she later married John Flowers), who was known by the traveling public as one of the best hotelwomen in Texas. From 1910 the train made a 20 minute lunch stop at Elgin and Mrs Flowers fed the passengers. After Mrs Flowers\' death in 1926 the hotel had several owners. It burned in 1952.

properties.name: McCreery's Garage
properties.description: Posted by Thegnu McCreery\'s garage was in the ground floor of the Rivers Building. The people in this picture (L to r) Beatrice Huey, B Aubry, R W McCreery, Emmitt Wade.

properties.name: McGee Shoe Shop
properties.description: Posted by Thegnu McGee\'s Shoe Shop has been in operation for as long as anyone can remember, at least since the 1920s. James McGee is the current proprietor. His father Ross McGee is in the picture. The equipment remains largely unchanged as you can see from the sewing machine in the foreground of the old picture and a picture taken of it in the shop in 2003.

properties.name: Moving the Taylor House
properties.description: Posted by Thegnu In early 1900s Dr T B Taylor moved to Elgin from Paige, where this house was originally built. He moved it twice within Elgin and finally to Bastrop when he retired. This picture from 1908 shows the second move within Elgin as the house is rolled using a winch hooked to a post in the middle of Main Street. The move took a month and the family lived in the house in transit.

properties.name: Mutual Lumber Company
properties.description: Posted by Thegnu Mutual Lumber Company 1914. Originally this lumber yard was located where Elgin City Park is shown on this map. But when the ladies of the New Century Club decided to landscape a park on that site, the lumber company moved to this new location. Only the front of the building remains today.

properties.name: Puckett's gin
properties.description: Posted by Thegnu Puckett\'s gin was built in 1912 and burned in 1924. A new one was built in 1925 at the same location.

properties.name: South (Brick) School 1898
properties.description: Posted by Thegnu Many in Elgin remember this school. Built in about 1897-8 (when this picture was taken) it was torn down after it had been unused for years, in the 1960s.

properties.name: aerial view 1950s
properties.description: Posted by Thegnu
